revision.comment: [[User:Monkbot/Task 9: Ship infobox lists|Task 9]]: convert line-break list(s) to unordered list(s) in ship infobox templates;

(1921 – 23) *B Blumenfeld (1923 – 38) *Krupp Reederei und Kohlenhandel GmbH (1938 - 45) *''unknown manager'' (1945 – 46) *Soviet Government (1946 - 58) | Ship registry =*{{flagicon|United Kingdom|civil}} [[London, England]] (1921 - 23) *{{flagicon|Weimar Republic|civil}} Hamburg, Germany (1923 - 33) *{{flagicon|Germany|Nazi}} Hamburg (1933 - 45) *{{flagicon|United Kingdom|civil}} London (1945 - 46) *{{flagicon|Soviet Union}} Soviet Union (1946 - 58) | Ship route = | Ship ordered = | Ship builder = Eltringham's, Ltd. | Ship original cost = | Ship yard number = | Ship way number = | Ship laid down = | Ship launched = Sometime in 1921 | Ship completed = August 1921 | Ship commissioned = | Ship decommissioned = | Ship christened = | Ship acquired = | Ship maiden voyage = | Ship in service = | Ship out of service = 1958 | Ship identification =*United Kingdom Official Number 146080 (1921 - 46) *{{ICS|Golf}}{{ICS|Mike}}{{ICS|Quebec}}{{ICS|Juliet}} | Ship fate = Removed from all shipping registries in 1958 | Ship status = | Ship notes = }} {{Infobox ship characteristics | Hide header = | Header caption = | Ship class = Cargo ship | Ship tonnage =*{{GRT|2,879}} (1921 – 45) *{{GRT|2902|link=off}} (1945 - 58) *{{NRT|1,675}} (1921 – 45) *{{NRT|1,696|link=off}} (1945 - 58) *4,450 [[deadweight tonnage|DWT]] | Ship displacement = | Ship length = {{convert|304|ft|8|in|m|2|abbr=on}} | Ship beam = {{convert|44|ft|1|in|m|2|abbr=on}} | Ship height = <!--{{convert|xx|ft|x|in|m|2}}{{convert|xx.x|m|ftin}}--> | Ship draught = {{convert|23|ft|0|in|m|2|abbr=on}} | Ship depth = {{convert|20|ft|5|in|m|2|abbr=on}} | Ship decks = | Ship deck clearance = | Ship ramps = | Ship ice class = | Ship range = | Ship power = 288 nhp | Ship propulsion = Triple action steam engine | Ship speed = <!--{{convert|xx|kn|km/h}}--> | Ship capacity = | Ship crew = | Ship notes = | Ship armament = none }} |}
The '''''Bernhard Blumenfeld''''' was a {{GRT|2,879}} [[cargo ship]] that was completed in 1921 as the SS ''Dalewood'' by Eltringham's, Ltd., [[Willington on Tyne]], [[England]]. She was sold to a German company in 1923 and renamed the ''Bernhard Blumenfeld''. She was sold again in 1938 and renamed the ''Carl Jüngst''.
This ship was seized by the [[British Army]] in the port of [[Kiel, Germany]], in May 1945 and given to the [[Ministry of War Transport]] which renamed her the ''Empire Durant''. In 1946, she was donated to the [[Soviet Union]] and there renamed the ''Tambov''. She was deleted from the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] shipping registries in 1958.
==Description== This ship was built in 1921 by Eltringham's, Ltd., [[Willington on Tyne]], [[England]].<ref name=Ships>{{cite book |last1= Mitchell |first1=W.H. |last2=Sawyer |first2=L.A. |year=1995 |title=The Empire Ships |page=not cited |publisher= Lloyd's of London Press Ltd |location= London, New York, Hamburg, Hong Kong |isbn=1-85044-275-4}}</ref><!-- She was yard number xxxx.<ref name=xxxx/>-->
This ship was {{convert|304|ft|8|in|m|2}} long, with a beam of {{convert|44|ft|1|in|m|2}}. She had a draft of {{convert|20|ft|2|in|m|2}} and a draught of {{convert|23|ft|0|in|m|2}}. She was assessed at {{GRT|2,879}}, {{NRT|1,695}}.<ref name=Blumenfeld30>{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=30b0146.pdf |title=LLOYDS REGISTER, NAVIRES A VAPEUR ET A MOTEURS |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=20 July 2011}}</ref> Her [[deadweight tonnage|DWT]] was 4,450.<ref name=Times220222>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Wm. France, Fenwick & Co Ltd |day_of_week=Wednesday |date=2 February 192 |page_number=20 |issue=42962 |column=A }}</ref>
This ship was propelled by a 288 [[nominal horsepower]] [[triple expansion steam engine]] that had cylinders of {{convert|23|in|cm}}, {{convert|33|in|cm}} and {{convert|62|in|cm}} diameter by {{convert|42|in|cm}} stroke. The engine was built by Eltringham's.<ref name=Blumenfeld30/><!-- It drove a single screw [[propeller]] and it could propel the ship at about {{convert|xx|kn|km/h}}.<ref name=xxxx/>-->
==History== ''Dalewood'' was built in 1921 for W France, Fenwick & Co, Ltd., London.<ref name=Mariners>{{cite web |url=http://www.mariners-l.co.uk/EmpireD.html |title=EMPIRE - D - E |publisher=Mariners |accessdate=20 July 2011}}</ref> She was completed in August.<ref name=Blumenfeld30/> The United Kingdom Official Number 146080 was allocated.<ref name=ID>{{cite web |url=http://convoyweb.org.uk/signal/index.html?search_all.php~signalmain |title=Signal Letters Database |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=20 July 2011}} (Enter GMQJ or Empire Durent in relevant search box - ''Note'' the typo Dur'''e'''nt.)</ref> In 1923, she was sold to the B. Blumenfeld Kommandit Gesellschaft auf Aktien, Hamburg and renamed ''Bernhard Blumenfeld''.<ref name=Ships/> The Code Letters RDSN were allocated and her port of registry was Hamburg.<ref name=Blumenfeld30/> With the change of Code Letters in 1934, she was allocated DHCG.<ref name=Blumenfeld37>{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=37b0109.pdf |title=LLOYDS REGISTER, NAVIRES A VAPEUR ET A MOTEURS |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=20 July 2011}}</ref>
In 1938, the ''Bernhard Blumenfeld'' was sold to the [[Krupp|Krupp Reederei und Kohlenhandel]] GmbH, [[Essen]] and renamed the ''Carl Jüngst''.<ref name=Ships/> Her Code Letters and port of registry remained unchanged.<ref name=Jungst38>{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=38b1011.pdf |title=LLOYDS REGISTER, STEAMERS & MOTORSHIPS |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=20 July 2011}}</ref> In May 1945, the ''Carl Jüngst'' was seized by the [[British Army]] at [[Kiel, Germany]].<ref name=Ships/> Declared a [[prize of war|war prize]],<ref name=Times070945>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Prize Courts |day_of_week=Friday |date=7 September 1945 |page_number=1 |issue=50241 |column=B }}</ref> she was passed to the MoWT and renamed the SS ''Empire Durant''.<ref name=Ships/> She regained her Official Number 146080 and was allocated the Code Letters GMQJ.<ref name=ID/> She was assessed as {{GRT|2902|link=off}},<ref name=Ships/> {{NRT|1,696|link=off}}.<ref name=ID/> In 1946, the ''Empire Durant'' was donated to the [[Soviet Union]]. She was renamed the ''Tambov'',<ref name=Ships/> serving as the [[mother ship]] for Soviet fishing fleets. In May 1950, the ''Tambov'', along with 30 trawlers, called at [[Mount's Bay]], [[Cornwall]], for refueling. This fleet was on a voyage from the [[Baltic Sea]] to the [[Black Sea]],<ref name=Times220550>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Russian Trawlers Again Anchor |day_of_week=Monday |date=22 May 1950 |page_number=4 |issue=51697 |column=G }}</ref> where they were to fish for [[sprat]]s.<ref name=Times230550>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Russian Trawlers Set Sail |day_of_week=Tuesday |date=23 May 1950 |page_number=4 |issue=51698 |column=B }}</ref> ''Tambov'' was deleted from shipping registers in 1958.<ref name=Ships/>
